characters: RED HAIR AND LESS LINES ON HER FACE.
ON THE BOARD. BELOW IT, EXAMPLES
OBSCURED BY THE CAKE BOX SHE CARRIES. SHE TURNS A CORNER
INTO THOSE OF AGATHA AND ISAAC...
..-HE CHANGES INTO YOUNG WALTER. AT THE BOTTOM HE COLLIDE
"TQ SIRIUS, IN EXCHANGE FOR MY NIGHTMARES, WALTER, XXX."
WITH A WOMAN AND TUMBLES TO THE GROUND. HE SITS UP, COVER
AND, PASSING THE STEPS, COLLIDES INTO SOMEONE AND TUMBLES
FOR EVERY YEAR WE KNEW HIM"
"BE SURE YOUR SIN WILL FIND YOU OUT."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A signpost reads: "THE STEPS TO HEAVEN." Below it, anothe adds: "WARNING: UNSAFE FOOTING. DON'T STRAY OFF THE PATH. Beyond them, STEPPING STONES disappear into darkness. The WIND picks up as we head into the marsh. Listen to it It carries INDISTINCT, TROUBLED WHISPERINGS. A DOG, a 95-lb pit bull, 90 of which is pure terrifying muscle, sits on a stone halfway across. An ANTIQUE SILVER COLLAR glints around its neck and its eyes... its eyes ar black, bottomless void. The whispers SWIRL AROUND it, get louder and louder, and more and more troubled...

dialogues.speaker: A RED SCREEN. ODD...
dialogues.text: -..it seems alive. Moving. Flowing.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: "You can call me Fingerling. It's not my real name, but comes from a book I read as a child, 'Fingerling at the Zoo.' Paper flap long gone, it had a green, hardback cover and mottled texture, and was possibly my very first book. Funny, I can't recall what it was about, the only thing I remember is the name. 'Fingerling.' I wished it was mine. Now it is,‚Äù WIDER ANGLE: WALTER SPARROW lies on his back in a cobbles road, staring at the BLOOD seeping from his head. As we PULL UP {looking down on Walter), we might notice t specific paths his blood has chosen through the cobblesto pathways that depict a number... ...the number 23.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER UP
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the screen BLURS as images {THE MOVIE IN REVERS FLASH PAST SUPER FAST-MO. The date COUNTS DOWN, stopping

dialogues.speaker: SUPER UP
dialogues.text: NORMAL SPEED: a WOMAN walks her BULLDOG down a STREET. She stops for some aimless window shopping. A cat MEOWS. dog turns and stares. The woman moves on but the dog won't budge. She tugs on leash. It GROWLS. She follows its stare to Walter, sittin in a truck, half-eaten pastrami sandwich in hands. He's staring right back at the dog. Walter MEOWS. The dog BARKS. The woman, shocked, notices the words "ANIMAL CONTROL OFF engraved on the truck's side. Suddenly fearful, she check her leash and pulls the dog away. Walter MEOWS once more, then chuckles and resumes his lun

dialogues.speaker: INT, TRUCK
dialogues.text: Stuck in traffic. The dashboard clock reads 4:58 p.m. Wal CB radio CRACKLES into life. A female voice:

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: Unit 5, come in. We have a U.S.S. Walter stares at the clock. It clicks to 4:59.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'd never thought much about destiny, but, maybe this was mine. Then again, things didn't really start here... The screen BLURS once more as we FAST-MO BACK IN TIME to:

dialogues.speaker: SUPER UP
dialogues.text: NORMAL SPEED: LIGHTS flash on a stunning CHRISTMAS TREE, We're in a HALLWAY at EVENING-TIME. Walter stares into a tinsel-edged, snow-dusted mirror, uncomfortable in suit and tie. ROBIN SPARROW, Walter's son and best friend, comes upstai Juggling. .

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: The truth?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: You look great.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter speaks to the bathroom door:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: How are we doing in there? The door opens. AGATHA SPARROW blows into a tissue, her r eyes and runny nose failing to diminish her sexiness. She in her underwear.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: I think you may be going alone. {a beat) Do you hate me?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: {looks her up and down) As much now as the day I met you. He fondles her neck, giving her goose bumps. All these ye of marriage and she still gets the bumps.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: I might be contagious.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I might be immune. His hand moves lower.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: What about the party?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Like anyone's going to miss me.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: What about the cake?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I'd like two words on my tombstone: "What if?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter passes drunk Yuletide revelers. A large CAKE BOX i on his passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: What if I'd said screw the cake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snowflakes are falling as Walter walks past CAROL-SINGERS cake in arms. He enters a PUB, the "MAN'S BEST FRIEND."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The local ACO's Christmas party. A small BAND (each membe dressed like Father Christmas) sets up. Walter adds the cake (a Dalmatian pup in Santa hat) to th table. SYBIL, an aging man-eater with too much make-up an well-endowed bosom barely contained by a red dress, sidle

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Single tonight, Walter? She pulls a SPRIG OF MISTLETOE from the depths of her bos

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: What if Agatha had come?

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: is where it's happening. Alcohol has been consumed. Walter sits alone with a slice of cake. Sybil drags him o the floor and throws her arms around him. Her clutch tigh She whispers into his ear. He stares at her, horrified. S whispers again. He breaks away.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What if I'd only been a bit more...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Sybil, I-- {the song ends} --wouldn't "wag my tail" with you in the cloakroom if I was in heat and you were the last "bitch" on Earth. Everyone stops and stares. Stares become laughs and snigg

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...tactful? Quieter, even?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stares at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Do you read me, Unit 5? I repeat, we have an undesirable scavenger sighting. Walter Sparrow, I know you're there.  He grabs the radio.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It's one minute to five, Sybil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sybil mans the dispatch.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Then we're agreed: you're still on duty. Happy fucking birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An undesirable part of Chinatown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old CHINESE MAN leads Walter via the kitchen to the ba door. He nods at it, afraid. Walter pushes it open. GRRR.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, WANTON PLEASURE
dialogues.text: Walter straps on PROTECTIVE SLEEVES. He pulls a MUZZLE an FLASHLIGHT from his truck, then a DOG POLE. Tests it. It He checks the time. Mutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only working street lamp flickers and dies. Walter flips on the flashlight. A sign reads: DEAD END. H points the beam to the end: a ragged, brick wall. No dog. line of DUMPSTERS provides plenty of lurking spaces. Walter inches down, pole at the ready, like a cop. He nea the end. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Meow. GRRR. He smiles. Moves onward, The PIT BULL (seen earlier) waits between two dumpsters. bares its teeth, eyes dripping with evil, glinting in the

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Man's best friend, my ass.  6. Walter switches the flashlight to WIDE BEAM and puts it d He extends the pole and steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Come to daddy. The dog SNARLS, backs against the wall, and BARKS.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Feisty little foe, aren't you? Perhaps you'd like to hear a story? He recounts the following in LOVING STYLE, adding SUBTLE GESTURES, luliing the curious canine into a false sense o security. (PARTS OF THIS SHALL BE ANIMATED)

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Once upon a time there lived a dog. Now this dog led a life of terror, fearing no one, but over time he realized, though his teeth were sharp and belly full, his heart was empty. He wanted a friend. He starts inching strategically forward.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Alas, all the other animals feared this four-legged fiend so he set off, journeying this way and that, to lands far, far away, hoping to find someone who knew not of his reputation. One day he happened upon a small, wooden shack with a smokeless chimney above. He suspends the pole above the dog.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: The door hung open and inside sat an old, thin man. His lonely eyes matched the dog's heart and when he beckoned it in the dog was overjoyed. That night, smoke drifted out the chimney, but oh, what odd-smelling smoke this was. You see, the land was China, and in China... In one swift movement, Walter whips the pole down, the dr string falling around the dog's neck. He yanks it tight.

dialogues.speaker: ...-THEY EAT DOGS
dialogues.text: The dog SNARLS and BARKS. Walter pulls out the muzzle and waits. His prisoner calms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moral of this story, you ask? He strokes the dog's head. A NAME TAG dangles from its co

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Stay out of goddamn Chinatown, my dear... He turns the tag over.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: -Ned. NED clamps its teeth over his arm. Walter HOWLS. Ned won' let go. He loosens the draw string. Ned releases his jaws, tugs h head free and bolts. Blood seeps through Walter's sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter storms out of the alley, sees Ned fifty yards away staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So you didn't like my story, huh? Fine. I can take criticism. He throws his stuff in the truck and pulls out a TRANQUIL GUN. Loads it. Marches towards his foe. Ned runs. Walter runs after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha locks up for the night and hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Ned bounds into a UNIVERSITY CAR PARK, waits for Walte to catch up, then bounds off again, like he's playing a g -- Agatha browses STALLS in a quaint MARKET SQUARE, TRADE are packing up for the day. -- Ned races down a street, stopping in front of a LIGHT APARTMENT BUILDING. Walter approaches. Ned races off. ~- Agatha waits beneath a lamppost, the market now a ghos town. -- Walter approaches Ned, waiting for him in front of a B The bus suddenly pulls away revealing a ROAD SIGN for "CASANOVA'S PARK." Ned races off.  8. -~ Agatha checks the time. Shivers. Glances about the squ at the SHOPS around the perimeter. ~~ Ned pauses at the foot of A STEEP FLIGHT OF STEPS. Che Walter is still in pursuit. He is. -~ Agatha browses aisles in a SECONDHAND BOOKSTORE. A BOO falls off a shelf right in her path, startling her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter turns a corner, puffing, and falls to his knees. N stands a few yards away, beside the PINK NEON SIGN of "TH SHELL‚Äù HOTEL (though the 'S' of Shell is unlit so the nam appears "HELL"). A board reads: "VACANCY."

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I'll give you Hell, alright. (aiming) Sweet dreams, furball. Ned runs into the road. A car BLASTS its horn, SCREECHES a halt. It moves on. The road...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There are so many what ifs. ...is empty, Ned staring at him from a CHURCH across the street, It BARKS. Enters the GRAVEYARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter follows his prey down row after row of graves.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Go ahead, buddy. Choose your spot. Ned heads to an ISOLATED GRAVE, disappearing behind the GRAVESTONE. Walter approaches. Takes a deep breath. Spins around the grave, gun at the ready. Ned.., ...IS NOWHERE TO BE SEEN. Walter, puzzled, looks about. He glances at the grave. It belongs to a "LAURA TOLLINS." The WIND picks up. Leaves BLOW across the ground. In the distance, against the SETTING SUN, he sees the SILHOUETTE A MAN. Watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter enters, BANDAGING HIS ARM. He looks once to his le once to his right, then left again, searching for Agatha.  9. sees a secondhand bookstore, "A NOVEL FATE." Walks up. Pe in the window.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What if. The only thing I know for sure is, I_was late. That's all it took. Agatha is inside. She's reading a BOOK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter rants to Agatha.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: ...the fucker was called "Ned." Ned for chrissakes! Know why someone calls a ninety-five pound pit bull Ned? Nasty Evil Dog, that's why. Well, next time I see it it's gonna be Nedd -- (pronounces second D) -- Nasty Evil Dead Dog. I'm telling ya, that mangy little sucker has ‚Äòhorse feed' written all over it and that's nothing compared to what I'll do if I ever meet the cretin who-- Agatha puts her finger over his lips.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Shush. Take a deep breath. It's your birthday, remember?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about that. How come we go to see your friends on my birthday?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Because you don‚Äôt have any. Walter tries, but can't really argue with that.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So: older, bitten, spending an evening in hell... (points to her book) ...I suppose I'm buying that for you, too?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: I think you might be, yes. He takes it from her. The tattered cover reads:  io.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Hardly the most imaginative of titles. What is it, part of a series?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: It's good. You should try it.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Books--

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: --are for people with no imagination of their own. I know. You don't know what you're missing.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: And yet, life goes on.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, RESIDENTIAL STREET
dialogues.text: Walter and Agatha walk along, hand in hand. (STILL IMAGES

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: February 3rd. That makes me Aquarius, one of the most innovative signs of the zodiac, a collective characterized by an acrobatic mind, a visionary, occasionally rebellious nature, a genius bordering on insanity, able to meet any challenge. Remember Thomas Edison? Charles Darwin? Rasputin? Jules Verne? That isn't all. Experts say Aquarians are philanthropists. Love is their driving force. Friends are vitally important. They reach a house with BALLOONS tied to the front gate, painted to look like variations of Walter. Walter scowls.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I, am living proof of the fallacy of astrology. Agatha drags him through the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ISAAC FRENCH, dashing in a tuxedo, opens the door. Watch carefully and you'll notice he pays a little too much attention to Agatha.  11.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Sorry we're late, Isaac.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Nothing a kiss won't cure. He offers his cheek to her. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: How's the arm, birthday boy?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Just waiting for it to drop off.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Good job it didn't bite you somewhere else then, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evidence of several PARTY GAMES having been played (pin t tail on the donkey, indoor hoopla, etc) is visible. Agatha plus twenty of her BOOKISH FRIENDS, all wearing PA HATS, pay close attention to Isaac -- acting the total ho and just finishing explaining the next game to them. A SKELETON sits in the corner. It also wears a party hat.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Does anyone have any questions? How about you, Walter? walter sits in an armchair picking at the remaining crumb of his birthday cake, a pile of weird and wonderful GIFTS beside him.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You're going to hand out those little cards you're holding, all of which are blank except for one saying ‚ÄòMurderer‚Äô and another saying ‚ÄòDetective.' Then you're going to turn out the lights and we all roam about the house in the dark trying not to break anything, and not owning up if we do, until the person with the 'Murderer' card ‚Äòkills‚Äô one of us. The victim should then move away from the killer before waking the neighbors with an ear-splitting scream, at which point the lights will come on and, assuming the police don't arrive, we all start guessing who the killer is.  12.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Sounds like someone has played before. He hands out the cards.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Everyone ready? People nod. Isaac walks to a FUSEBOX in the HALLWAY. All the lights go out and suddenly we are playing...

dialogues.speaker: ..-MURDER IN THE DARK
dialogues.text: We see VARIOUS SHOTS of SHADOWS roaming through the house accompanied by the usual GIGGLES/APOLOGIES/GASPS as peopl bump into each other.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: slips inside a BEDROOM and safely watches the goings-on through a crack in the door. Suddenly we hear:

dialogues.speaker: A WHISPER
dialogues.text: I don't think hiding out in the bedroom is quite in the spirit of the game. Agatha turns around, whispers back:

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: who's that?

dialogues.speaker: A WHISPER
dialogues.text: Who do you want it to be? Agatha's hands fumble over someone's face.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Walter? The whisper and face do indeed belong to Walter.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Oh God, I'm sorry. I had no idea he was planning a games night. What are you doing in here, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Oh, you know, I thought I'd sneak into a bedroom and see if I got lucky.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: And did you?  13.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I certainly did. He starts to kiss her face.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Who do you think the killer is?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Do you care? He kisses her again. This time she responds. The kiss qui grows in intensity Walter runs his hands over Agatha's body, working his way over her breasts to her neck, continuing on up to her ear before descending back down to her neck. Then, very slowl Walter starts to squeeze...

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Mmm... Walter Sparrow... It's soft and sensual and utterly sexy. Or at least, that how it starts out. But Walter's grip gets tighter and tig Agatha's eyes open. She tries to scream but his mouth is pressed to hers. Walter‚Äôs eyes snap open... which is when Agatha realizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Agatha walk to the front door, arm in arm. Wal opens the door, is about to step inside when...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: pops up from the couch. A GIRL'S HEAD follows it up.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (to Agatha) Remember the days we used to go for late night walks in the moonlight?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: There's no moon tonight. She moves to the door. Walter takes her hands.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: We can take advantage of the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Someone already did.  14. She again tries to reach the door. Walter prevents her. H nods to a HAMMOCK on the verandah and winks.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Remember those days, too?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Walter, it's freezing out here. What's gotten into you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I just thought, seeing as it is my birthday, and we've just spent the evening--

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: --I'll get a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: No! I mean, there's one in the truck.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: You're giving me a dog blanket?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Take my coat.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: You'll freeze to death.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Not if someone keeps me warm. Agatha smiles. Walter wraps his coat around her and they

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: I can't believe you killed me.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It was fun. The look on your face...

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: At least you got some interesting gifts. Those commemorative silver dollars from Fred, for example--

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: --I don‚Äôt need a hobby, Aggie. I have you. Agatha snuggles up to him.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: How's it feel?  15.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: To be a cold-blooded killer? (looks around) Strangely familiar.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: I meant, to be another year older.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Oh, Devastating.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But it's-- (imitating Isaac) --nothing a kiss won't cure. He offers his cheek to Agatha. She digs him in the ribs t kisses him. The front door opens. Robin pokes his head ou He's in his pajamas and robe.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Mom? Dad? I thought I heard voices.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: If someone was in bed asleep like they were meant to be, they wouldn't have heard anything. She approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: How's that homework looking?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Like it's finished. Agatha strokes his face affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Don't be long. I'll make cocoa. She goes inside. Walter and Robin exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Well, don't just stand there. You'll catch yourself a death. He holds open his coat, beckoning his son to cuddle up wi him. Robin does, gladly.  i√©.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: We fell asleep. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Back door?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: She went down the alley. He hands Walter a PRESENT from his robe pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I forgot to give you this.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I accept bribes at any time of day. Father and son smile. Walter opens the present: a hand-painted "FATHER OF THE Y mug.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: She's a nice girl, Robin. Make sure she stays that way. He squeezes Robin's hand, then leads him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha pours hot milk into three mugs. Walter and Robin e Walter transfers his cocoa into his new FOTY mug. The Spa all smile and head off to bed, Walter turning out the lig as they go. Seconds later, the moon emerges from a cloud. Agatha's book, "The Number 23," lies on the table, glinti in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fresh-faced DR. ALICE MORTIMER, 26, checks a file. A mug serves as a pencil-holder. It's almost empty.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALICE MORTIMER
dialogues.text: This is your first bite?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: First animal one, yes. (off her look) My wife. She has these... gnawing urges. In her sleep.  17.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALICE MORTIMER
dialogues.text: Tell me about Ned. What would you do iff you came across him again?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Put my foot on the gas and accelerate.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALICE MORTIMER
dialogues.text: You'd run away from him?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: No, I'd crush the furry fleabag beneath my tires. {off her look) I'm joking. This whole thing's a joke.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALICE MORTIMER
dialogues.text: Mr. Sparrow, animal control regulations state that any officer suffering at the hands of an animal must undergo psychological counseling to evaluate their state of mind.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You don't seriously think I'm going to snap because some crafty little canine chowed down on my arm?

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALICE MORTIMER
dialogues.text: This is your first bite. A person's first bite can have traumatic consequences.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Traumatic consequences? I'm not traumatized. A little embarrassed, perhaps. He rolls up his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: This is not trauma. This is stupidity. I gave him my arm on a platter. Can't blame a species of lower intelligence for that. That'd be like shouting from the rooftops after the time I let my wife choose the color for the living room walls. Not that women are a species of lower intelligence. Dr. Mortimer writes in her file. Walter tries to see what

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALICE MORTIMER
dialogues.text: Have a good day, Mr. Sparrow.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What? No. Agatha‚Äôs the most intelligent woman I know. What she sees in me I'm not sure. I love my job. And I'm good at it.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALICE MORTIMER
dialogues.text: Ned got away.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Well, yes. But--

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALICE MORTIMER
dialogues.text: --don't worry, apart from a flawed sense of humor I've given you a clean bill of health. You're not a danger to anyone. That's why you can go.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It is? He relaxes, glances at the clock -- just gone 10 a.m.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But they've given me the whole day off for this.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ALICE MORTIMER
dialogues.text: Then make the most of it. I won't tell. Walter walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: DR, ALICE MORTIMER
dialogues.text: Mr. Sparrow? What color did she choose? For the walls.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Red. Blood red. Walter stands in the doorway gazing at the BLOOD RED WALL He half-heartedly rummages through various BIRTHDAY GIFTS jigsaw, beer-making kit, cardigan, new deck of cards, etc

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Agatha, Agatha, Agatha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter munches off a plate of COOKIES as he pours a glass MILK. He pauses. Transfers it into his FOTY mug.  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His 'n' hers bedside tables -- Agatha's cluttered, Walter having alarm clock and lamp only. Walter lies on the bed. Bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter lies on Robin's bed. He gets up. Looks around the room. Passes a MODEL OF A HE made out of empty matchboxes. He picks up the top box. Th helix collapses. Walter, sheepish, leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wall to wall BOOKS, plus a DESK and OLD TYPEWRITER. Walter stands in the doorway. He steps in, then thinks be of it. Turning to leave, he sees "THE NUMBER 23" on the d He picks it up. Stares at the cover. Turns to the BLURBS the back:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "A heart-wrenching odyssey into paranoia," "One of the most horrifying metamorphoses ever told." "Beware the dog next door." (a beat) Beware the dog next door?

dialogues.speaker: INT, BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Walter settles on the bed with the book. He turns to AN O BATTERED DOLL on Agatha's bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Don't you tell her about this. He turns to page one. Clears his throat. Reads aloud:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "You can call me Fingerling. It's not my real name, but comes from a book I read as a child, 'Fingerling at the Zoo.' Paper flap long gone, it had a green, hardback cover and mottled texture, and was possibly my very first book. Funny, I can't recall what it was about, the only thing I remember is the name. ‚ÄòFingerling.' I wished it was mine. Now it is." He frowns. Flicks to the front and finds the disclaimer:  20.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "All the characters in this book are fictitious, and anyone finding a resemblance to actual persons, living or dead, should proceed no further."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter pulls books off the shelves. Checks their DISCLAIM

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: All the characters... any resemblance... entirely coincidental. (different books) Purely coincidental. Wholly coincidental .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stares at "The Number 23" disclaimer. He continues

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "Do not concern yourself with my nom de plume. My real name matters not, nor my physical description. Imagine me, if you must, as someone you once knew. Someone, perhaps, you liked."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An URBAN SCHOOL. TOWER BLOCKS are visible out the windows

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "As a kid I was top of my class." Young FINGERLING raises his hand to a question. He has a somewhat sallow complexion.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: "Not because I liked studying, but because I realized an education was my best shot at getting out of town. See, the stork dropped me in a small dustbowl of a town." The view out the window CHANGES ACCORDINGLY. Buildings disa tall elm trees sprouting in their pi The sk ppear p. g place. y turns biue and is fu ¬∞. rdsong. The room interior aiters too, as do the kids, the teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingerling walks along, laughing gaily with pals.  21.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "There wasn't anything wrong with it. As far as boring towns go I'm sure it ranked above average. It was just boring. So were the other kids." His pals VANISH. He walks alone, kicking a soda can.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "They're probably all still there." He passes the TOWN CEMETERY.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "No one ever left. But I was destined for other things."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's face pales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingerling does his homework.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Much as I loved him, I wasn't gonna end up like my dad. It was bad enough people said I looked like him." He looks up. His FATHER sits behind a desk, maniacally ta away at a calculator.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "He was an accountant and fully expected me to take over the business he had built. Still, he loved me." His Father motions for Fingerling to continue his homewor

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "In his own special way."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter lowers the book. Even he doesn't know exactly what he's feeling. He reads on:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "My father's inability to express warmth was more than compensated by my mom. In her eyes I could do no wrong.‚Äù  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingerling sits at the table, still doing homework.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "I wanted to be like her. She understood what made people tick.‚Äù His MOTHER {her kitchen clearly portraying her as someone fond of baking) slides a plate of COOKIES and a glass of MILK in front of him. She closes his books and strokes hi head, tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter glances at his milk and cookies.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: If you become a dogcatcher, I am gonna sue your ass. He continues, quietly for a few seconds, until:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "My mom was thrilled when, on my eighteenth birthday, I announced that I wanted to be a..."

dialogues.speaker: ENT. KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Breakfast-time, PRESENTS (books on finance, etc) cover th table in front of Fingerling, 18 today. Fingerling's Mother's mouth hangs open. She's thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks up from the book.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Detective. He wants to be a detective. (to Agatha's doll) You hear that? A detective! Visibly relaxed, he continues reading, but as he does, hi voice grows heavy...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Not so my father.‚Äù

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the other end of the table sits Fingerling's Father. H seething.  23.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It made his hatred of our neighbor, old Mrs. Dobkins, even stronger, and she'd been dead ten years. She lived next door and our houses were identical, except for..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter freezes. His face drains of color.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ".,,the gardens. You see, her house fell on the bend, and thus, her back garden was twice the size. But it wasn't that that angered my dad. Oh no..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tidy place, the only fault being the FENCE running down one side. Unlike the one that takes over at the bottom an comes up the other side, this one is OLD AND RICKETY.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "...Picture if you can..." We creep towards it, peek through a KNOT HOLE, travel int

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‚Äú,..a world where the grass is forever thigh-high, A world where wild animals could feel at home, their only hazard being Alfie, Mrs. Dobkins' cocker spaniel." ALFIE appears, following a scent.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: "I always knew when Alfie was up to something. How? Simple.‚Äù Alfie comes across a rabbit. The chase is on. A SAXOPHONE tune fades in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Fingerling stops playing the SAXOPHONE and looks ou of his window, which looks out over:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: "Swaying grass. It was as if a tornado was signing its name in it.‚Äù  24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter turns the page swiftly.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "Dad was incapable of seeing the beauty. He also didn't think it funny when Alfie sought a little R and R in our garden,‚Äù

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alfie sunbathes on the lawn. Suddenly, he's on red alert.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: "It was my job to catch him." Fingerling pounces on him, Alfie darts off, scampering th way and that.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "From this, a detective in the making was born. Let me explain."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter closes the book and searches through wardrobes. A_ YAPS incessantly.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "It was my eighth birthday and Alfie's gift sounded like exercise. Except it wasn't. He just stood still and barked."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter searches cupboards, under beds, etc.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "There was no answer when I rang Mrs. Dobkins' doorbell so I went through the side gate."

dialogues.speaker: EXT, MRS. DOBKINS' HOUSE
dialogues.text: Fingerling passes through the side gate, Alfie in arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters the KITCHEN, checks VARIOUS ROOMS -- all empty.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Soon I was going upstairs. At the top, Alfie leaped from my arms."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alfie runs into a room. Fingerling follows. It's MRS. DOB BEDROOM and Alfie is on the bed, licking Mrs. Dobkins' fa She's been dead a good fourteen hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter spies the HATCH to the LOFT.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: "It was an hour before the doctor arrived, and in that uncertain hour my eight-year-old mind raced."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter climbs into BOX HEAVEN. Starts moving stuff.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "I decided Mrs. Dobkins had been killed by a man with a deranged mind, a mind such as our town had never seen before. No one would be safe from him, not even his loved ones. Especially his loved ones." He pauses in the shadows, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "Of course, the doctor later concluded it was a heart attack but by then my mind had been opened to a whole new existence." He reaches out and opens an OLD CHEST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha arrives home. She sees Walter's truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha pops her head into the LIVING ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Yoo-hoo,. She heads UPSTAIRS, notices a SCUFF MARK on the wall half up. Navigating the LOFT STEPS (down) she enters their BED Several wardrobes are open. She returns to the loft steps

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Walter? She climbs up. The LOFT is empty.  26. She checks the TOILET, the BATHROOM, even her LIBRARY. Next comes ROBIN'S BEDROOM. Empty. She picks one of Robin shirts off the floor then notices the helix.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Walter. The window draws her gaze -- a LIGHT is on in the GARAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha approaches the garage. She opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits on the floor, his back to her. The chest serv as a backrest and is empty, its contents (OLD PHOTO ALBUM TROPHIES, CHILDHOOD MEMORABILIA) spread around him.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Here you are. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I'll clear it up later. Agatha walks over, freezes on seeing the book in his hand

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Oh. My. God. I don't believe my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Did you read this? He folds a page corner and closes it. It's "The Number 23 Agatha nods.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What did you think of it?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: I thought it was brilliant. Style's a bit odd. It reads a bit... raw.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: This Fingerling guy--

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Fabulous name.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Yeah. What did you make of him?  27.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Oh, I loved him. At least, I did in the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What do you mean, "in the beginning"?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Well, he... How far are you?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Page eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Oh. Haven't been reading long, then?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It feels like I have.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Darling, this is wonderful. Good for you. I'll fix your favorite for dinner tonight. She leaves. Walter follows after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha enters through the BACK DOOR and washes her hands. Walter stops in the doorway. Agatha transfers ingredients from the fridge to the table ONIONS, TOMATOES, MINCE, etc.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Honey, you're letting in a draught. Walter puts the items back in the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Walter! I just got that out. He walks outside then reappears with a stack of PHOTO ALB etc, and dumps it on the table. He holds up "THE NUMBER 2

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It's me, Ag. Me.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Walter points to PHOTOS of him growing up, his parents, t house, their car, shots of him in the garden, an OLD, RIC FENCE in the background.  28. Another is of Walter and a COCKER SPANIEL. Then the view from a bedroom -- a sprawling jungle of a xrden next door

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Some little twerp has written a book about me. Agatha can't help it -- she laughs.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Sorry. What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I mean, somebody has taken MY life, MY childhood, MY memories, and based a character on it. Fingerling.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous. Fingerling's nothing like you.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He's everything like me. His past is my past. They've stolen it. This Kretts person has... he's plagiarized my life. He hands her ANOTHER BOOK. Paper flap long gone, it has a green, hardback cover and mottled texture. Its title is:

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: "‚ÄúFingerling at the Zoo."

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: My mother read it to me when I was young.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Honey, lots of people would have read this as a kid.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: No, but... She points to various photos.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: There are many towns like your hometown, each with streets like yours. With houses like yours.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: And dogs next door?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Your neighbor had a dog? Shocking.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It wasn't called Alfie. It was called Chief. "Mischief" my dad called it. It used to escape all the time. That's why I became who I am. A dogcatcher.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Fingerling's a detective.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So he used a little imagination. It's like he's implying I'm not good enough!

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: I finally understand why you don't like to read.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You remember the old woman next door? Well she died. On MY eighth birthday. He sinks into a chair -- mentally exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: So there are similarities. Read on. You'll soon realize Fingerling's very different from you. I promise. She puts the book in his hands. Walter stares at it, the words "THE NUMBER 23, A NOVEL OF OBSESSION BY TOPSY KRETT staring right back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin enters, playing with a Rubick's cube. He hangs up h schoolbag and makes his way to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I'm home. I'm hungry. I'm-- He pauses. Backtracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter reads in an armchair. He doesn't notice Robin star at him from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: INT, KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Robin enters. Agatha is cooking.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Oh hi, sweetie. How was school-- What's happened? You're very pale.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Dad's reading.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Yes, I know! Wonderful, isn't it? Bit of a shock, admittedly.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: But... how... why... when... I didn't even know he could read. Well, of course I knew he could, I just... what's he reading?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: His life-story.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Huh? He picks at some food scraps. Agatha smacks his hand with spoon and he goes to the sink to wash his hands.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Dinner might be rather odd tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Why? What are we having?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Robin, darling, I love you deeply, but humor is not your strong point. She pushes the door shut, quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin sits opposite his dad, watching. Walter ignores him He moves to Walter's armrest. Reads along.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: What kind of name is 'Fingerling?‚Äô Walter shuts the book. Robin, a little hurt, leaves the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon is waning.  31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner-time for the Sparrows. Spaghetti bolognaise. They serve themselves, awkward, fleeting smiles the currency o conversation,

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Why would someone write a book about you?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: That, son, is a very good question.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Am I in it? I mean, if it is about dad, shouldn't I have a starring role?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Yes, you should. And yet, you don't. I wonder what that means?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: The author knew you'd be a scene- stealer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLOCK clicks to 8 p.m. It begins to CHIME. Walter reads in his armchair. Agatha reads in her armchai Robin does homework on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: 1i P.M. as the clock FINISHES CHIMING.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Robin. Robin sighs and rises. He kisses each as he says:

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Night, Mom. Night, Dad. Walter doesn't respond. Robin exits.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to run a bath. Walter -- still totally oblivious.  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha soaks in the tub. Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enters, post-bath and in her nightgown. The bed is em

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She peers over the banisters -- Walter is still reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha takes the book from Walter, folds down a page corn and pulls him up. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha pulls back the covers for a pajama-clad Walter and gets into bed. She goes to kiss him. He shies away.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: How far are you?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He's just spent his first month's wages on a diamond ring for Fabrizia.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Ah yes, his Italian girlfriend. And you told me I was the first girl you ever loved.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: She could be you. (off her look) Am I being silly?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Every time I read a book it's like the author managed to steal a part of me I thought only I knew about. I'll write my own one day and do the same to someone else. No, you're not being silly. Paranoid, yes. (she snuggles up) But I love you all the same. Walter kisses her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I love you, too. He clicks off the light.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light comes on. Walter walks to the sink and turns on the cold water tap. Holds his hand underneath. The coolness of the water wakes him. He looks around, confused. He's been sleepwalking. He's drawn back to the white, porcelain sink. It's spatte with red. He looks at his hands. More red. It's BLOOD. He checks himself, concerned. Then he sees it -~ an EMPTY SLOT in Agatha's KNIFE BLOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter walks up, one step at a time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clicks on the light. Agatha is snuggled under the cove He peels back the covers: BLOODSTAINED SHEETS appear. He throws off the covers. Freezes.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: has been stabbed to death, multiple times. The KNIFE stil protrudes from her body.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: No. He pulls out the knife. Stares at it. Throws it aside and collapses over Agatha, sobbing. Pulls her into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: A nightmare. Nothing but a nightmare. Put her back, close your eyes, and it'll be alright. Everything will be all right. He lays Agatha down tenderly and shuts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Please. He opens them. Agatha is still dead. Tears stream down hi cheeks. He SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Sorry! I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I'm sorry!  34. The light comes on. Agatha stares at Walter. He's clutchi his ghoulder. She moves his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Oh God, I almost drew blood. Walter follows her gaze. Teeth marks puncture his skin. H looks at his pajamas, the sheets, Agatha‚Äô's nightgown -- knife, no blood anywhere. Agatha kisses his shoulder. Walter takes her head in his hands, gazes at her, and kisses her passionately.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER UP
dialogues.text: Sybil works the dispatch, headset on.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: What kind of noise? A 'PUTT-PUTT-SCREECH' comes over the speakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's truck sits in the shade under a tree. A 'PUTT-PU SCREECH' comes from his open window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stops making the noise.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I'll call a mechanic.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Already done. He's on his way.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Let me know the deal, ASAP.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Will do. Unit 5 out. He hangs up the receiver. Reassures himself:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It's just one day. He turns to "The Number 23" on the next seat. Picks it up  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locking down on Walter's truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bird poop hits the windshield. Walter doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking through a telescope (into the apartment opposite) a GORGEOUS GAL, pacing back and forth in her underwear. Fingerling, now grown up and wearing POLICE UNIFORM, turn a somewhat sheepish, SLEAZY LITTLE MAN. The Man redirects telescope and Fingerling looks again, this time into an a white LIVING ROOM. In the center is a CHAIR. Above it hangs a NOOSE.

dialogues.speaker: SLEAZY LITTLE MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She gets on the chair, puts it around her neck, and just stands there. The Gal enters frame, does exactly this.

dialogues.speaker: SLEAZY LITTLE MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Then she gets down. Been doing it for two hours. She recently stopped seeing some guy who was doing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingerling exits one apartment block and heads for the ot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingerling knocks at Apartment #92- (the last number is missing). No answer. He tries next door, #925, flashing h badge at an old, Chinese woman.

dialogues.speaker: PINGERLING
dialogues.text: Police. Can I use your balcony? Hard to tell if she understands. Fingerling enters anyway

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingerling climbs around the dividing wall and peeks roun the edge of the French doors. SUICIDE GAL, on the chair, sees him and quickly puts the noose around her neck. Fingerling steps into the open, hands up.  36.

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: I'm not here to hurt you. I'm here to help. He opens the doors. The walls, ceiling, furniture -- everything is covered with PLAIN, WHITE PAPER. Letter-siz Fingerling, spellbound, inches his way to the couch and s

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: So. What's with the Hammermill mosaic?

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: I know what you're up to, this ‚Äòtry to befriend me' crap. Come any closer and I'il jump.

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: I'd rather you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: Why should you care?

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: Today's my birthday. If you jump it'll be my worst one ever.

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: You're pathetic. I swear, move and I‚Äòll fucking jump.

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: If you want to die, die, but hanging's painful as hell. What's worse, most people screw up making the noose. All they achieve is a permanent necklace, a grisly reminder of how utterly pathetic they are. If you're serious about ending it there are far more effective ways.

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: (dumbfounded) Such as?

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: Well, you live on the ninth floor. Haven't you ever wanted to fly? Suicide Gal laughs. A beat. Fingerling offers her his han

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: It really is my birthday.  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio CRACKLES into life, startling Walter. SYBIL‚ÄôS VOICE Unit 5, come in. Walter! He thinks for a second then picks up the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Sybil? Sorry I haven't got back to you. We're running some tests... diagnostic things.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: And? Talk to me, Walter. The city's canine population is running amok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No mechanic anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It doesn't look good. Something to do with the... fan belt... timing mechanism? (to non-existent mechanic) That's what you said, isn't it? (to Sybil) Yeah. He's getting some parts. I'll let you know as soon as I'm mobile.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (testy) Fine. HQ out. Walter turns back to the book.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "The woman warns me to be careful: she was a together-person once."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suicide Gal makes coffee. The decor here matches the livi room, Even the coffee jar is wrapped in paper.

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: Now I'm a bad person. I don't want to turn you bad. You seem nice.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "I should have got out of there but I'm real curious."  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingerling and Suicide Gal sit on the couch with coffee.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ‚ÄúWe play this cute waiting game." Suicide Gal peels a sheet of paper off the couch. Etched into the leather ARE LOTS OF WORDS, SEEMINGLY SCRA AT RANDOM, WITH NUMBERS ASSIGNED TO THEM... ... ALL ADDING UP TO 23.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "Then she said it.‚Äù

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: This number... this FUCKING number... it rules my world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CB radio crackles into life, again startling Walter.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Unit 5, come in. Do you copy, Unit 5? Walter? Walter ignores her, reads LOUDER to drown her out.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "It's all my father's fault.‚Äù

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suicide Gal stares at a MAN'S NAME on the wall: TIMOTHY C HUNT accompanied by the numbers 110/66/63, 2/12/9, 23.

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: He said he was a genius and that he'd figured out how to beat it. He said I'd be safe. He said--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GIRL (Suicide Gal aged 8) sits in bed, knees pulled up tight to her chest. Her FATHER sits on the edge of her be His eyes are fraught with anguish. His shirt 1s BLOOD~STA

dialogues.speaker: GIRL'S FATHER
dialogues.text: --Daddy loves you and he's going to do something that guarantees his little girl gets to grow up to be just who she wants to be.  39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her Father holds a GUN to his head, hand shaking.

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All he had to do was kill himself and the curse would have ended with him. He lowers the gun, unable to do it.

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I guess he just didn't love me enough. INT. SUICIDE GAL‚ÄôS LIVING ROOM - CONTINUED Suicide Gal paces back and forth as she rants:

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: It's everywhere. Times. Dates. Numbers of buses. License plates. Pages of books. Even elevator floor lights. Soon I realized it was in my name. The words I spoke. Nothing was safe. Nothing. My favorite color's pink. You know what pink is? She rips a piece of paper off the wall, Behind it are a m of words and their corresponding sums. She points to the words RED and WHITE. Red = 27. White = 65. 27+65=92.

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: Pink has four letters. 92/4 equals...

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: Twenty-fucking-three.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "I'll be honest -- I didn't get it. I asked her the only question I could muster."

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: Any more coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's truck is EMPTY.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Walter, this isn't funny. Pick up. I said, pick up, damn you. We have a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYBIL‚ÄôS VOICE (CONT'D) U.S.S. two blocks away so even if your truck's still 0.0.S...

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PARK
dialogues.text: Walter reads as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "Tt tell her a story.‚Äù (a beat) A story? The bastard tells stories? (continues) "I tell her the one about my Uncle Charlie, how one day he read in his stars he was gonna fall in love with a woman wearing green so he walks around all day until he finds one. Six months later they married." (not reading) What kinda lame ass story is this? {continues ) "The woman tells me..."

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: ..-you're lying. Fingerling holds up a finger -- he hasn't finished yet.

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: Two years later the woman in green divorces my Uncle and takes half of everything he's got. Fingerling peers out the French doors -- still open.

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: He's out there now, at this very moment, still searching for a woman in green. Figures he just got the wrong one.

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: This is meant to make me feel better, how?

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: You look smarter than my Uncle Charlie. Suicide Gal smiles.  41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits on a bench.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "She has a face meant to smile." Walter smiles -- he'd have been proud of that story.

dialogues.speaker: INT, SUICIDE GAL'S HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Fingerling and Suicide Gal walk to the door. She opens it

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: I promise I'll be okay. Thank you. She kisses him on the cheek. Fingerling steps out. As he walks down the corridor:

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: Officer? Happy birthday. How many is it?

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: Twenty... five. Suicide Gal smiles again.

dialogues.speaker: INT, ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Fingerling descends. Ali the floorlights are working.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "I get in the elevator. I get out the elevator."

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "IT exit the building. I wonder if Sleazy is watching me and look up to see when...‚Äù Fingerling looks for Sleazy when... THUD!

dialogues.speaker: SUICIDE GAL
dialogues.text: hits the pavement beside him. EXT. PARK - DAY - UNKNOWN POV... ...watching Walter from beside an OLD OAK TREE.  42.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "That night I eat out with Fabrizia."

dialogues.speaker: INT, RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: FABRIZIA wipes cream off Fingerling's chin. She's feeding him strawberries.

dialogues.speaker: FABRIZIA
dialogues.text: Bi-zarre. But what does she mean, it rules her world?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "I'm not surprised in the slightest when she announces..."

dialogues.speaker: FABRIZIA
dialogues.text: I wanna go see her place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the paper has gone, revealing the full, terrifying ex of Suicide Gal's obsession with 23.

dialogues.speaker: FABRIZIA
dialogues.text: This is so bi-zarre, To think it happened on your 23rd birthday. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. The only light comes from the open bathroom door

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "At home, Fabrizia is buzzed." Suddenly there's WATER MOVEMENT, a LOUD GASP FOR AIR, and

dialogues.speaker: FABRIZIA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Again.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "God, I love her."

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "The next day, I traced this ex- the woman mentioned." Fingerling enters a BEDROOM where a MAN lies in bed, DEAD A knife protrudes from his chest.  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter frowns -~ unsettled, yet not sure why. In the dist you might notice NED beside THE QLD OAK TREE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingerling holds up an EVIDENCE BAG. Inside is the KNIFE.

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: Forensics matched it to her. His SERGEANT checks a report.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Guess this is what she meant by being a bad person.

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: Yeah. If it's all right with you, I'm gonna take the rest of the day off. Feeling a bit queasy.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Dead people will do that to ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingerling exits. He looks around, once to his left, once his right, then again to his left.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "I didn't feel bad about lying. There was just something I had to do."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look closely and the hairs on Walter's nape are prickling

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "EZ mean, it was only one day." His mouth falls open with a bad case of d√©ja vu. He stare into space... until the book slowly draws him back. INT, SUICIDE GAL‚Äò'S LIVING ROOM Fingerling studies the CRAZY WRITING on the walls. Around top of the walls is the ALPHABET plus EACH LETTER'S NUMBE

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "You might laugh at what I did next, but I bet you'll try it." Fingerling pulls out his NOTEPAD, Starts scribbling.  44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only floorlights 1, 5, 8 and 9 work. As Fingerling descends, he stares at the notepad. On it a a bunch of letters and numbers. Inside a circle at the bottom...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Surely it was just a coincidence? I mean, a name's just a name, right?" ...is the number 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingerling waits outside an office. The clock reads 7:30

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: 30 minus 7 is 23. Fabrizia raps on the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabrizia eats, Fingerling doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: FABRIZIA
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: Yeah, Fine.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "T don't tell her that, including us, but excluding the waiters, there are twenty-three people in the restaurant. I do tell her about the crazy woman's boyfriend. Her reaction is..."

dialogues.speaker: INT, CHEAP HOTEL
dialogues.text: Fabrizia pays for a room.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "...pure Fabrizia.‚Äù

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabrizia unlocks a door. Fingerling stares at the room nu  45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabrizia pulls a packet of STOCKINGS from her purse. She throws them at Fingerling and lies on the bed, putting he wrists against the headboard.

dialogues.speaker: FABRIZIA
dialogues.text: Don't worry, they're cheap ones. Fingerling TIES EACH WRIST to a bedpost, starts unbuttoni her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: FABRIZIA
dialogues.text: No. Rip it off. Rip it all off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter shifts in his seat, somewhat uncomfortable. He loo around, checking no one is watching him. Reads on, quietl

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: "I do as I'm told, She spreads her legs and instructs me to look in her purse, I find another packet of stockings. I tie her legs. Then I remove my clothes and climb aboard."

dialogues.speaker: INT, HOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Fingerling makes love to Fabrizia. Gentle.

dialogues.speaker: FABRIZIA
dialogues.text: Pretend you have a knife in your hands. A beat. Fingerling squeezes his right hand into a fist an traces it over her body at a steady height of six inches. Fabrizia squirms beneath him -- almost like he does have knife. Fingerling gets more and more into it and when Fab goes to say something, he clamps his left hand over her m

dialogues.speaker: FINGERLING
dialogues.text: Quiet, bitch, or you die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingerling and Fabrizia head home.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Of course, I would never really harm Fabrizia. I loved her. And she loved me.‚Äù Fingerling looks at Fabrizia. She gazes lovingly at her n DIAMOND ENGAGEMENT RING.  46.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "But that night I had the most unsettling nightmare imaginable.‚Äù

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PARK
dialogues.text: Walter reads on, then lowers the book, his mind racing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter pulls into the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has covered one wall with paper. The alphabet is written at the tep. Below it, the numbers 1 to 26. He wri 'WALTER SPARROW‚Äô up. Proceeds as follows:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Oh fuck. He continues. A=1; L=12; T=20; E=5; R=18. Total: 79. S=19; P=16; A=1; R=18(x2); O=15; W=23. Total: 110. Walter stares at it. Then he writes: 7+9=16 and 1+1+0=2 w gives him 16+2=18. He sighs. Suddenly, he pauses. He scribbles 'PAUL' between Walter and Sparrow. P=16; A=1; U=21; L=12. Total: 50. 5+0=5.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: 16 plus 2 plus 5 equais... He turns. Stares at "The Number 23" lying on a work bench INT. "A NOVEL FATE‚Äù USED BOOKSTORE ~ AFTERNOON The book is on the counter. Walter waits as a SALESPERSON types into a computer. She frowns, swivels the monitor to him, "NOT FOUND" flashes on screen.

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: Are you sure you bought it here?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Of course I'm sure. What kind of idiot mistakes where he buys a book? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (a beat} It was here. I bought it on my birthday for my wife.

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: Shouldn't she be buying you stuff if it was your birthday?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: There was this dog. I was late and... Can you help me or not? The Salesperson examines the book.

dialogues.speaker: . SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: It's self-published, self-printed and by an author I've never heard of. She types "KRETTS, T" into the computer.

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: And old Topsy hasn't written a thing since. She hands the book back. Walter doesn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: That's all you can tell me? Dead end, dead end, dead end?

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: Am I correct in thinking you want to get in touch with the author?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You are very correct.

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: Then may I be so... original... as to point this out? She points to a MAILBOX ADDRESS inside the back cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter hits redial on the PHONE by the FRONT DOOR, a PHON BOOK by his feet. Agatha comes home.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: So this is where you are. Sybil's called me at least a dozen times. He shushes her, speaks into the phone in a very odd voice  48.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Hello, I wonder if you can help me?

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE VOICE
dialogues.text: Mister, you call once more and I'm calling the cops. Dial-tone.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Why are you speaking in a funny voice? Walter holds up "The Number 23."

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I'm trying to contact the bastard thing's author but the only clue is this. {opens to mailbox address) And the minimum wage little shit who works there won't tell me anything!

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Walter, what is going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter leads Agatha in. Scribbles and their corresponding tallies covers the wall.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Oh my. Walter points out VARIOUS DISCOVERIES.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: My name equals 23. My birthday is two three. My driver's license. Social security number. Everything! He holds up "The Number 23."

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Don't tell me it isn't me. This proves it. I'm telling you, the little fucker used me.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Walter.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He has, Aggie. Not only that, the book's driving me nuts. I can‚Äôt explain it, but, I'm imagining all (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: sorts of weirdness. It's like it's... imitating my life.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Is this what you've been doing all day?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: How does he know so much about me? Why did he chose me?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: He didn't.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Why can't you see it? You've read it and you know me better than I do! Agatha takes the book, opens to his bookmark -- about hal

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: You haven't even finished it.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I've read all I need to read.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: You've read all you want to read. You've concerned yourself with the minutia and drawn wild conclusions from them, What about the fact that Fingerling kills Fabrizia then confesses and is sentenced to life in an asylum?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He kills her?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Stabs her to death. She thrusts the book into his hands, turns, and walks out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha is chopping vegetables. Walter appears in the back doorway with a SHEET OF PAPER. watches Agatha, lovingly. Suddenly he notices THE KNIFE. He walks up and, from behind, takes it from her. She swiv around but before she can say anything she notices his ey are tearing up. He puts the knife in the sink. Takes her  50.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Walter leads Agatha in.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Why this color?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Why did you choose this color? For the walls. -

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Walter, no more games. She pries her hands free and walks to the door. Walter's words stop her in her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I dreamt I killed you. (a beat) Last night. With a knife. While you slept. Just like Fingerling did.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Walter, this isn't funny.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: No, it isn't. He looks at LOVING FAMILY PHOTOS on the mantelpiece.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Sure, there are discrepancies. Fingerling‚Äôs a cop. I'm a dogcatcher. He met Fabrizia when he was 21 whereas I met you when I was...

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Twenty... three.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Do you remember the day we met?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Of course I do. September 14th.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Nine fourteen. 9 plus 14 is...  51.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Twenty... three.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: The day we married?

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: A month later. October... 13th. A solemn beat.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Suicide gal said it ruled her world. She killed because of it. Then she passed it on to Fingerling. On his birthday. He found it applied to him, and look what it made him do. Don't you see, Ag? Fingerling called it fate. Do you know what fate is? He hands her the sheet of paper. "FATE" is written on it, along with its value, which is...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Thirty two. 23 reversed. I love you, and would never ever harm you, but Fingerling said that, too. I'm scared, Ag. I'm so, so scared. He wraps his arms around Agatha. Over his shoulder, she s at "The Number 23."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sparrows sit around a foodless table. Robin is buildi a HOUSE OF CARDS. The doorbell RINGS. Robin runs to it. Seconds later, he veturns with a PIZZA.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Nineteen ninety-five plus tip, he said. Fifteen percent is...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Twenty three. Agatha hands Robin twenty five.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Tell him to keep the change.  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha pretends to read but secretly watches Walter stare "The Number 23." Robin, scribbling into a schoolbook, loo

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: We live at number 1814. Walter and Agatha look at him, confused.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: 1814? 18 is 1 plus 8 which makes 9. 9 plus 14 is 23. Big deal, you might say? Well, what's strange is this. Look at it the other way around: 14 is 1 plus 4 which makes 5, and 18 plus 5 is also 23.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Don't talk nonsense, Robin.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: It's not nonsense. 18 plus 5 ig 23. That's not all. 18 plus 14 is 32.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Twenty-three reversed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Spooky, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha pulls the covers back for Walter. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: AGATHA
dialogues.text: Everything is going to be fine. Nothing's going to happen to me. You love me. I love you. He gets into bed. Agatha kisses him and snuggles close. W clicks off the light.

dialogues.speaker: DARKNESS
dialogues.text: awakes. He turns to the clock. It's 3:22 a.m. Suddenly, t next number falls, CLICKING THUNDEROUSLY to 3:23. Walter rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads downstairs.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses by the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is coming up. Birds are chirping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha's outline is visible under the covers. An agonizin beat. -: She stirs. A hand appears, plops down on Walter's side. Agatha‚Äôs head emerges. Walter's side of the bed is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agatha enters. Walter is fast asleep on the sofa. His feet protrude from under a blanket. They are BOUND TOGETHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SKELETON from Walter's birthday hangs in a corner. Is (a psychology professor) finishes a silent read of a LETT FROM AGATHA. He wears a YELLOW TIE. He looks up. Walter gazes out the window (we're high up) at the surrou UNIVERSITY. Isaac joins him.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Do you regret it? Not finishing college.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: My parents' accident changed my focus in life. As a result, I met Agatha. No, I don't regret it at all. (a beat) Besides, there's something unsettling about these places.

dialogues.speaker: TSAAC
dialogues.text: Probably all the books around the place. we have five libraries, you know. He picks up "The Number 23."  54.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Sounds like a fascinating read.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Meaning that's all it is. A book. So I am crazy.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Good Lord, no. Twenty three is very good at this particular game.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What do you mean? What game?.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Paranoia. Oh yes, there's a fair bit of literature on the 23 enigma.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: There is?

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: There are 23 axioms in Euclid's geometry. The human body consists of 46 chromosomes, 23 from each parent. Blood takes 23 seconds to circulate. Shakespeare was born on the 23rd April. He died on the 23rd April. The Mayans believed the end of the world would occur in 2012. 20 plus 12 is--

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: --twenty three reversed.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Yes. The exact date is December 23rd.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So it's true. The number's... God?

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Two divided by three is point 666, 666 being the number of the Devil.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It's the Devil?

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: What's true is that certain people take delight in perpetuating the number's infamy. Aleister Crowley. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: R A Wilson. William S. Burroughs gave it a certain degree of credibility when he noted a 23 connection between a boat sinking and a plane crash.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What kind of connection?

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Burroughs knew a Captain Clark who ran a ferry from Tangiers to Spain. One day, Clark told him he'd been doing so for 23 years without accident. That day the ferry sank, killing Clark and all his passengers. Burroughs got home, turned on the radio and heard that an airplane traveling from New York to Miami had just crashed also. The Captain was named Clark, too. No prizes for guessing what the flight number was.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I'm not the only one. It‚Äôs omnipresent.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Some would say of course. After all, the world does spin on an axis of 23 degrees. 23.5 if you want to be picky, but 5 is simply 2 plus 3.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But 23 is also the lowest number unattainable on a dartboard with only one dart.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: True. Interesting that your name begins and ends with Ww.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: W is the 23rd letter of the alphabet.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: I do believe there are no names in the Bible beginning such. The Book of Revelations has only 22 chapters, you know, and that predicts--

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: --the end of the world. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {points to "The Number 23") And that predicts the end of my world.

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Yes, it sounds like a most fascinating book. Walter paces, his distress suddenly worrying Isaac. He passes

dialogues.speaker: ISAAC
dialogues.text: Of course, there exist far too few stories where the main character plays the saxophone. I used to play, you know. Always fancied myself as the next John Coltrane. I wasn't. aware you also played. Agatha's always said you were... well, not much of a hobby person.
